# Network Topologies Complete Exercise - COMPLETE SOLUTION

## SECTION 1: Topology Fundamentals

# Two types of network topologies:
# 1. Physical topology: Actual physical layout of cables and devices
# 2. Logical topology: How data flows through the network

# Can these differ?
# Answer: Yes (yes/no)

# Example of difference:
# Physical: Star topology (devices connected to central switch)
# Logical: Could function as bus (with hub) or star (with switch)


## SECTION 2: Physical vs Logical Topology

# Physical topology shows:
# 1. Cable routes
# 2. Device locations
# 3. Physical connections
# 4. Distance between devices

# Logical topology shows:
# 1. Data flow paths
# 2. Communication patterns
# 3. Broadcast domains
# 4. Network segments

# Token Ring example:
# Physical: Star topology (devices connect to MAU)
# Logical: Ring topology (token passes in circular order)


## SECTION 3: Bus Topology - Description

# Structure:
# All devices connect to: Single central cable (the bus or backbone)
# Data travels: In both directions along the bus
# Cable type: Coaxial cable (10BASE2, 10BASE5)

# Requirements:
# Both ends need: Terminators
# Why: Prevent signal reflection

# Data flow:
# Broadcasts to: All devices
# Only intended recipient processes it
# Others: Ignore it


## SECTION 4: Bus Topology - Collision Detection

# Access method:
# Full name: Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection
# Abbreviation: CSMA/CD

# Process:
# 1. Device listens before transmitting
# 2. If collision occurs, wait random time
# 3. Retry transmission


## SECTION 5: Bus Topology - Pros and Cons

# Three advantages:
# 1. Simple and inexpensive
# 2. Easy to implement (small networks)
# 3. No additional hardware needed

# Six disadvantages:
# 1. Single point of failure: Cable break disables entire network
# 2. Difficult to troubleshoot
# 3. Limited scalability
# 4. Collision domain: All devices share bandwidth
# 5. Security issues: All devices see all traffic
# 6. Difficult to expand

# Modern use:
# Status: Virtually obsolete (legacy 10BASE2/10BASE5 Ethernet)


## SECTION 6: Star Topology - Description

# Structure:
# All devices connect to: Central device
# Central device options: Hub, switch, or router
# Cables: Individual cable to each device
# Data flow: Through central device
# Most common: Modern Ethernet (802.3)


## SECTION 7: Star Topology - Hub vs Switch

# With Hub (Legacy):
# Behavior: Hub broadcasts to all ports (like bus)
# Collision domains: Single collision domain
# Operation: Half-duplex

# With Switch (Modern):
# Behavior: Switch forwards only to destination port
# Collision domains: Each port is separate collision domain
# Operation: Full-duplex possible
# Efficiency: Much more efficient


## SECTION 8: Star Topology - Pros and Cons

# Six advantages:
# 1. Easy to install and manage
# 2. Easy to troubleshoot
# 3. No network disruption when adding/removing devices
# 4. Fault tolerance: One cable failure affects only one device
# 5. Scalable: Easy to expand
# 6. Better performance: With switches

# Four disadvantages:
# 1. Single point of failure: Central device failure disables network
# 2. More expensive: Requires switch/hub
# 3. More cable: Each device needs separate cable
# 4. Central device capacity: Limited by port count


## SECTION 9: Star Topology - Variants

# Extended Star (also called Hierarchical Star):
# Structure: Multiple switches connected in hierarchy
# Layers: Core, distribution, and access layers
# Use: Common in enterprise networks

# Three-tier structure:
# Top: Core switch
# Middle: Distribution switches
# Bottom: Access switches connecting end devices


## SECTION 10: Star Topology - Use Cases

# Four modern use cases:
# 1. Modern LANs: Virtually all Ethernet networks
# 2. Enterprise networks: With hierarchical design
# 3. Home networks: Consumer routers/switches
# 4. Office networks: Workstations to switches


## SECTION 11: Ring Topology - Description

# Structure:
# Each device connects to: Exactly two other devices
# Forms: Circular pathway for data
# Data flow: Circular (unidirectional or bidirectional)
# Access method: Often uses token for transmission rights
# Redundancy: Can be single ring or dual ring


## SECTION 12: Ring Topology - Token Ring

# Standard: IEEE 802.5

# How it works:
# 1. Token circulates around ring
# 2. Device wanting to transmit waits for token
# 3. Device captures token, attaches data
# 4. Data travels to destination
# 5. Destination copies data, marks as received
# 6. Original sender removes data, releases token

# Status: Obsolete (obsolete/modern)


## SECTION 13: Ring Topology - Dual Ring

# Structure:
# Two counter-rotating rings
# Direction: Counter-rotating

# Benefit:
# If one ring fails: Use other ring
# Capability: Self-healing

# Technologies using dual ring:
# - FDDI (Fiber Distributed Data Interface)
# - SONET/SDH (telecommunications)


## SECTION 14: Ring Topology - Pros and Cons

# Four advantages:
# 1. No collisions: Token passing ensures orderly transmission
# 2. Equal access: Fair access for all devices
# 3. Predictable performance: Known maximum delay
# 4. Self-healing: With dual ring

# Four disadvantages:
# 1. Failure affects network: Single ring disrupted by one failure
# 2. Difficult to troubleshoot
# 3. Difficult to reconfigure: Adding/removing devices disruptive
# 4. Slower than switched star for small networks


## SECTION 15: Ring Topology - Technologies

# Token Ring:
# Standard: 802.5
# Status: Obsolete (obsolete, replaced by Ethernet)

# FDDI:
# Full name: Fiber Distributed Data Interface
# Speed: 100 Mbps over fiber
# Rings: Dual counter-rotating rings
# Use: Backbone networks
# Status: Mostly obsolete

# SONET/SDH:
# Type: Telecommunications networks
# Use: Ring topology for redundancy
# Status: Still in use for WAN backbones


## SECTION 16: Mesh Topology - Full Mesh

# Description:
# Every device connects: Directly to every other device

# Connection formula:
# Formula: n(n-1)/2
# 4 devices = 6 connections
# 10 devices = 45 connections
# 100 devices = 4,950 connections

# Characteristics:
# Redundancy: Maximum redundancy
# Cost: Maximum cost
# Cabling: Complex cabling


## SECTION 17: Mesh Topology - Partial Mesh

# Description:
# Some devices have multiple connections
# Not all possible connections exist

# Benefits:
# Redundancy: Balanced redundancy and cost
# Connections: Strategic connections
# Practicality: More practical than full mesh


## SECTION 18: Mesh Topology - How It Works

# Four key features:
# 1. Multiple paths between devices
# 2. If one path fails, use alternate path
# 3. Routing protocols determine best path
# 4. Load balancing possible across paths


## SECTION 19: Mesh Topology - Pros and Cons

# Five advantages:
# 1. High redundancy: Multiple paths if one fails
# 2. Fault tolerance: Network remains functional with failures
# 3. No single point of failure
# 4. Load balancing: Distribute traffic across links
# 5. High bandwidth: Dedicated links between devices

# Four disadvantages:
# 1. Very expensive: Many cables/connections required
# 2. Complex installation: Difficult to cable and configure
# 3. Complex management: Routing and troubleshooting difficult
# 4. Not scalable: Connections grow exponentially (full mesh)


## SECTION 20: Mesh Topology - Modern Use

# Physical mesh:
# Use: Rare (too expensive for full mesh)

# Logical mesh common in:
# 1. Internet backbone: ISPs interconnected
# 2. Cloud networks: Multiple paths for redundancy
# 3. SD-WAN: Multiple WAN connections
# 4. Wireless mesh: Wi-Fi mesh networks

# Four use cases:
# 1. WAN backbone: ISP and enterprise WANs
# 2. Data center interconnects: Between facilities
# 3. Critical systems: High-availability requirements
# 4. Wireless mesh: Wi-Fi mesh networks (Google Wifi, Eero)


## SECTION 21: Hybrid Topologies - Description

# Definition:
# Combination of two or more basic topologies

# Star-Bus (also called Tree Topology):
# Structure:
# - Star at access layer
# - Bus or star at distribution layer
# - Most common enterprise design

# Star-Ring:
# Structure:
# - Devices in star to MAU
# - MAU creates logical ring
# - Used in Token Ring networks

# Mesh-Star:
# Structure:
# - Core network in mesh
# - Access layer in star
# - Enterprise WANs with multiple sites


## SECTION 22: Hybrid Topologies - Pros and Cons

# Four advantages:
# 1. Flexibility: Combine benefits of multiple topologies
# 2. Scalability: Easy to expand
# 3. Reliability: Redundancy where needed
# 4. Cost-effective: Redundancy only where necessary

# Three disadvantages:
# 1. Complex design: Requires careful planning
# 2. Difficult to manage: Multiple topology types
# 3. Troubleshooting complexity: More variables to consider

# Three use cases:
# 1. Enterprise networks: Most large organizations
# 2. Campus networks: Multiple buildings
# 3. Data centers: Hierarchical design


## SECTION 23: Point-to-Point Topology

# Description:
# Direct connection between: Exactly two devices
# Dedicated link: Only two devices
# Bandwidth: Full bandwidth (no sharing)
# Configuration: Simple (simple/complex)

# Five examples:
# 1. Serial connection between routers
# 2. Fiber link between buildings
# 3. Direct cable between two computers
# 4. Leased line (T1, E1)
# 5. Point-to-point wireless link


## SECTION 24: Point-to-Point - Pros, Cons, Protocols

# Four advantages:
# 1. Simple: Easy to configure
# 2. Full bandwidth: No sharing
# 3. Secure: Only two devices
# 4. Low latency: Direct path

# Three disadvantages:
# 1. Limited: Only two devices
# 2. No redundancy: Single path
# 3. Cost per device: Expensive to connect many devices

# Three protocols:
# 1. PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol)
# 2. HDLC (High-Level Data Link Control)
# 3. Frame Relay (legacy)

# Four use cases:
# 1. WAN connections: Router to router
# 2. Building interconnects: Fiber between buildings
# 3. Dedicated circuits: Leased lines
# 4. Wireless bridges: Point-to-point wireless


## SECTION 25: Point-to-Multipoint Topology

# Description:
# One central device connects to multiple remote devices
# Also called: Hub-and-spoke
# Shared medium: All remote sites share central link
# Communication: One-to-many from central to many

# Four examples:
# 1. Wireless access point to clients
# 2. Satellite communication
# 3. Cellular tower to phones
# 4. Cable TV distribution


## SECTION 26: Point-to-Multipoint - Pros and Cons

# Three advantages:
# 1. Cost-effective: One central connection
# 2. Centralized control: Managed from one location
# 3. Good for distribution: Content delivery

# Three disadvantages:
# 1. Single point of failure: Central device
# 2. Shared bandwidth: All remotes share central link
# 3. No direct communication: Remote-to-remote requires central device

# Three use cases:
# 1. Wireless networks: AP to clients
# 2. Branch offices: Hub-and-spoke WAN
# 3. Broadcast services: Radio, TV, satellite

## SECTION 30: Network Design by Organization Size

# Small Office (1-20 users):
# Topology: Simple star topology
# Equipment: Single switch
# Redundancy: Minimal

# Medium Business (20-200 users):
# Topology: Hierarchical star
# Equipment: Multiple access switches, single/dual core switches
# Redundancy: Some redundancy

# Enterprise (200+ users):
# Topology: Hybrid (mesh-star)
# Design: Three-tier hierarchy (core, distribution, access)
# Redundancy: Full redundancy
# Paths: Multiple paths


## SECTION 31: Three-Tier Hierarchical Design

# Core Layer:
# Purpose: High-speed backbone
# Topology: Mesh or partial mesh
# Devices: No access devices (only infrastructure)
# Focus: Speed and reliability

# Distribution Layer:
# Purpose: Aggregates access switches
# Function: Routing between VLANs
# Policy: Policy enforcement
# Connections: Star to core, star to access

# Access Layer:
# Purpose: Connect end devices
# Topology: Star topology
# Security: Port security
# Segmentation: VLANs


## SECTION 32: Spine-Leaf Architecture

# Use: Modern data centers

# Structure:
# Every leaf connects to every spine
# Connections: Full connectivity

# Four characteristics:
# 1. Predictable latency (consistent)
# 2. High bandwidth
# 3. East-west traffic optimization
# 4. Scalable

# Benefits over three-tier:
# Better for: East-west traffic (server-to-server)
# Reduced: Latency
# Increased: Bandwidth


## SECTION 33: Wireless Topologies

# Infrastructure Mode:
# Topology: Star topology
# Center: Access Point (AP)
# Connection: All clients connect to AP
# Network: AP connects to wired network

# Ad Hoc Mode:
# Type: Peer-to-peer
# Connection: Devices connect directly
# AP required: No (yes/no)
# Limitations: Limited range and scalability

# Mesh Topology:
# Structure: Multiple APs interconnected
# Feature: Self-healing
# Benefit: Extended coverage
# Examples: Google Wifi, Eero, Orbi


## SECTION 34: Troubleshooting by Topology

# Bus topology troubleshooting:
# 1. Check termination
# 2. Test cable segments
# 3. Look for breaks or shorts

# Star topology troubleshooting:
# 1. Check central device (switch)
# 2. Test individual cables
# 3. Check port status
# 4. Verify link lights

# Ring topology troubleshooting:
# 1. Identify break in ring
# 2. Check all devices in sequence
# 3. Use beaconing (Token Ring)

# Mesh topology troubleshooting:
# 1. Identify failed paths
# 2. Check routing tables
# 3. Verify alternate paths working
# 4. Monitor link states

# Question 1: Most common modern LAN topology?
# Answer: Star (with switches)

hints: Physical topology: actual cable layout; Logical topology: how data flows (can differ)
Bus: obsolete, single coaxial cable, terminators required, single point of failure
Star: most common modern topology, central switch/hub, easy troubleshooting, scalable
Hub (legacy): broadcasts to all ports, single collision domain; Switch (modern): forwards to specific port, separate collision domains
Ring: circular, token passing (802.5), FDDI dual ring, mostly obsolete except SONET/SDH
Full mesh formula: n(n-1)/2 connections; 10 devices = 45 connections; very expensive but highly redundant
Partial mesh: strategic connections, balanced redundancy and cost, more practical than full mesh
Hybrid: combination of topologies (star-bus tree, mesh-star); used in enterprise networks
Point-to-point: exactly 2 devices, full bandwidth, protocols PPP/HDLC, used for WAN links
Point-to-multipoint: hub-and-spoke, central device to multiple remotes, wireless AP to clients
Three-tier hierarchy: Core (backbone mesh), Distribution (aggregates, routes VLANs), Access (connects endpoints in star)
Spine-leaf: modern data center, every leaf to every spine, predictable latency, east-west traffic
Topology selection: consider cost, scalability, reliability, performance, geographic layout, security
Small office: simple star, single switch; Enterprise: hybrid three-tier with full redundancy
Wireless: Infrastructure (star to AP), Ad hoc (peer-to-peer), Mesh (interconnected APs)
Troubleshooting star: check central switch, test individual cables, verify link lights
Bus uses CSMA/CD (listen before transmit); Token Ring uses token passing (orderly access)
Extended star (hierarchical star): multiple switches in hierarchy, common in enterprise
Star advantages: easy troubleshooting, scalable, fault tolerance; Disadvantage: central device single point of failure
